Vector projection appears everywhere in technical fields:

items.definition: When a ball bounces off a wall, we project its velocity onto the wall's normal to calculate the reflection.
PCA (Principal Component Analysis) projects high-dimensional data onto principal axes to reduce dimensionality.
Breaking forces into components along and perpendicular to a surface is projection at work.
Calculating lighting involves projecting the light direction onto surface normals for diffuse shading.

props.title: Deep Dive: This gives us a scalar that tells us how far along b the projection extends.

children.children: This scalar is the heart of vector projection - it's the coordinate that tells us exactly where the projection lands on vector b. Without it, we'd just know the direction (which is b's direction), but not how far to travel along that direction to reach our projected point.
Say vector b = (3, 4) has length 5. After computing the dot product a¬∑b = 15, we divide by |b|¬≤ = 25 to get scalar 0.6.
This means: travel 0.6 times the full length of b to reach the projection. Since b has length 5, we travel 0.6 √ó 5 = 3 units along b's direction.

Think of it like GPS coordinates on a highway. Vector b is the highway, and this scalar is like saying 'your destination is at mile marker 0.6' - it tells you exactly how far along the highway to go, as a fraction of some reference distance.

children.children: To find the actual projection vector, multiply this scalar by the unit vector of b. The scalar tells you 'how much', and b's direction tells you 'which way' - together they give you the complete projection.
